newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul prosecutors to question Kim's son again.
newsitem.headline: Seoul prosecutors to question Kim's son again.

text.p: South Korean state prosecutors will summon for questioning President Kim Young-sam's son on Thursday in connection with a probe into a scandal involving the younger Kim, a prosecution official said on Wednesday.
Kim Hyun-chul has denied allegations that he took kickbacks from companies in return for influence-peddling and that he meddled in state affairs.

The official confirmed a report by state-run Korean Broadcasting System (KBS) television that Kim Hyun-chul, president Kim's second son, would be summoned by 2:00 p.m. (0500 GMT) on Thursday. He declined to give any more information.
The younger Kim, who helped engineer his father's win in the 1992 presidential election, is also under investigation over allegations that he had kept part of the unspent funds.
He was questioned by prosecutors in February but cleared of any wrongdoing in connection with a loans-for-kickbacks scandal uncovered by the collapse in January of Hanbo Steel Co.
Hanbo's failure under some five trillion won ($5.6 billion) debt revealed a web of corrupt alliances between politicians, businessmen and bankers.
Two of his business associates have been arrested on charges that they took bribes in return for promises to lobby the younger Kim to help obtain government broadcast licences.
Last week the Chosun Ilbo newspaper reported Kim Ki-sup, a former top intelligence officer, had asked the Hansol Group to manage seven billion won. Hansol has denied the report.
